fields.text:
Inspired by the writings of Jane Jacobs, Manuel De Landa, landscape urbanists, Steven Johnson, and others on the organization of cities, the Possible City offers an alternative to the top-down and bottom-up planning of the past. It seeks to create a new relationship between citizens, organizations, government, design professionals and the physical, social, and economic spaces that they inhabit. The Possible City will be a framework for developing a symbiotic network of continuous experimentation, feedback, and synthesis that is more in-tune with the city as a complex and evolving entity.

What happens next will be powered by individual innovation and collaborative sharing. We are on the verge of a massive mutual co-arising. - Bre Petis (founder of Makerbot)

The Possible City seeks to create a local economy built around rebuilding the city. Our initial focus will be on the cities forgotten spaces — Those places which have for one reason or another vexed the established political and economic structures, those places for which existing planning processes and techniques have failed. We believe that the Possible City will emerge from these forgotten spaces, and that the plan for the  future city will emerge from the Possible City in a constant state of making and remaking. And because of our history, because we believe in the necessity of connecting the virtual with physical specificity, and because of its history and inherent qualities, the Possible City will focus its initial efforts in Philadelphia and Brooklyn.

Possible City is in the process of developing a series of tools to instigate this process:

Free Agent

Possible City is built to support the agency of individuals to instigate change in their own communities (and to eventually make a living doing it). Users of the site will be able to create Agent profiles through which they will interact with Projects, Lots, and other Agents. These profiles will allow Agents to share information about their location, their interests, projects they have "floated", Projects they have "grounded", Projects they are backing, Lots they are following, other Agents they are networked with, and skills and expertise they can bring to rebuilding their communities. People with particular expertise such as engineering, design, construction, community organization, planning, legal etc, can advertise these skills on their profiles. Initially, we will be on recruiting designers to populate the site with project ideas and developing tools for designers to instigate projects. Over time, designers will be able to pool resources and form loose collectives to work on projects -- a disruption of current design practice.

lotXlot

lotXlot is an application for mapping the city on a parcel by parcel basis. It allows Agents to locate "Lots" with specific characteristics, gather up-to-date data about them, add their own data, "Follow" them,  become "Stewards", and connect them with other Agents and Projects. The initial focus of lotXlot will be vacant lots, but every parcel in the city will have its own profile page and will be open to intervention. Lots can be networked together physically by location (clusters of lots connected to each other, corridors of lots connected by another physical structure in the city such as a transit line, or stream bed, and networks of lots - connected not physically but virtually by defining characteristics or uses)

Float

Float is an application that will allow Agents to "float" projects for specific locations in the city. The ideas can range from simple seed ideas to more fully realized projects. Once the ideas have been floated, other agents can comment, join, support, and fund the realization of the project.  Eventually, tools will be developed to help interested agents to "ground" the project - where the project transitions from the virtual space to physical ground.  Related projects can be networked with each other to allow those involved to share knowledge and resources and begin to populate the city with new emergent physical and social  structures.

Genesis

Possible City grew out of work that Douglas Meehan did starting in 2005 while a graduate student at the University of Pennsylvania School of Design. As a landscape architecture and urban planning student fascinated with the implicit promise embedded in the post-industrial landscape of cities, he signed up to work on organizing the Urban Voids: Grounds for Change design competition. Urban Voids, sponsored by the City Parks Association and the Van Alen Institute solicited innovative ideas for reclaiming Philadelphia's 40,000 vacant lots. He worked on developing the competition brief and helped facilitate a series of public input meetings which informed the final call for entries. 

Urban Voids: Grounds for Change produced a wide array innovative and inspiring entries, but as with most ideas competitions, after the initial excitement and a public exhibition, these ideas were reduced to piles of foamcore collecting dust in the dark basement of a non-profit. Seeking to avoid this fate, the City Parks Association enlisted Doug (who worked as a web designer and developer prior to graduate school) to create a website that would give the competition ideas an extended life. The website was initially conceived as place to organize and exhibit the competition entries and provide resources for interested parties to extract actionable items. But as he worked on the site, Doug began to think that it could become something more. He wondered if the site could become not only a one-way disseminator of information like pamphlets of old, but a two way exchange of ideas and inspiration. Doubtlessly, there were other piles of foamcore sitting in non-profit basements all over the country. Not only that, what about all of the speculative student work developed, with optimism and late nights, at design schools everywhere, now locked away in hard-drives and portfolios? And what about citizens outside of the design fields? Presumably, they might have some pretty good ideas too. 

The work culminated in Grounds for Change: Activating Vacant Land, now run by the Washington, DC think-tank, The Center for Community Progress, which displays and solicits ideas for vacant land in cities across the country. And, over the course of the past 6 years, similar ideas such as ChangeByUs, Neighborland, and Brickstarter have begun to take hold.

The Possible City is the next step in the evolution of this idea.
fields.title: Introducing the Possible City
fields.text_html:

fields.text:
Future Perfect is a new book by Steven Johnson that details the rise of decentralized network approaches to complex problems. In it he details a lot of the thinking that is driving Possible City and other similar projects such as Brickstarter  and Neighborland. 

This video gives a good overview of the book, as well as insight into the driving forces behind Possible City.
fields.title: Future Perfect
fields.text_html:
Future Perfect is a new book by Steven Johnson that details the rise of decentralized network approaches to complex problems. In it he details a lot of the thinking that is driving Possible City and other similar projects such as Brickstarter  and Neighborland. 

This video gives a good overview of the book, as well as insight into the driving forces behind Possible City.

fields.text:
Ecosistema Urbano is a loose collective of architects and planners based in Madrid, Spain. In 2006, they were finalists in the Grounds for Change design competition that I helped organize with the City Parks Association  and the Van Alen Institute. 

This year, they had an exhibition at the Venice Biennale of Architecture documenting some of their ideas for the future of design practice, community engagement, and what they call "network design".

We understand the role of the architect and urban planner is undergoing a huge transformation according to the new needs of contemporary society. This forces us to redevelop a whole “set of tools” to be able to meet these new needs and challenges. Under the title of DREAM YOUR CITY we explain these new tools or methods we are dealing with and the way we think network design can be applied to socially engaged designs for the creation of city spaces. This 90 seconds movie illustrates how we understand network design and how we specifically implemented it in Hamar or how it could be applied somewhere else.
fields.title: Dream Your City
fields.text_html:
Ecosistema Urbano is a loose collective of architects and planners based in Madrid, Spain. In 2006, they were finalists in the Grounds for Change design competition that I helped organize with the City Parks Association  and the Van Alen Institute.

We understand the role of the architect and urban planner is undergoing a huge transformation according to the new needs of contemporary society. This forces us to redevelop a whole “set of tools” to be able to meet these new needs and challenges. Under the title of DREAM YOUR CITY we explain these new tools or methods we are dealing with and the way we think network design can be applied to socially engaged designs for the creation of city spaces. This 90 seconds movie illustrates how we understand network design and how we specifically implemented it in Hamar or how it could be applied somewhere else.

fields.text:
Philadelphia has announced a new "Office of New Urban Mechanics" to dedicated to experimenting with new ways of providing services and tackling city problems.

Tech President sums up the development:

In Nutter's remarks Monday, he was essentially saying that he's starting up an office that will use technology and the concept of peer networks to let citizens help his administration get better at doing the things it was already supposed to be doing. That is one way to read this quote:

“To me, open government is about more than just sharing information or transparency. Those are critical components of it. But I think an open government is a conversation. It’s a process. It’s a new relationship ... Our agencies are constantly reminded that this is not about building better technology. It’s about rethinking how services are delivered and integrated across our city government. Our vision is to take every service that does not require a face to face interaction and making it available online so that our citizens can interact with the government any time, anywhere on any device and on their schedule.

Read more of Tech Presidents coverage  of this development.
fields.title: Philadelphia Office of New Urban Mechanics
fields.text_html:

fields.text:
The design of infrastructure has the power to dramatically shape urban form and life, functioning as the conduit for the ecological, social, and economic flows of a city. As we continue to retrofit existing city centers to support burgeoning urban populations, innovative and sustainable methods of enabling and managing these flows are needed. An emerging approach to this issue utilizes existing infrastructure as an armature, akin to the way epiphytic plants rely on host plants to augment their capabilities. Infrastructure that enhances or performs new functions while the existing structure that it overlays continues to perform its original function may be called “epistructure.” Epistructure can provide new services, enhance and amplify existing services, or even fully absorb the work of its host.

Unlike much infrastructure, which is—by definition—“under” and generally hidden from view, epistructure is on the surface, visible, and becomes an integral part of a city’s public space, identity, and maintenance programs. It, therefore, must serve aesthetic and social purposes in addition to its performative functions. 

Epistructure can be physical interventions, such green roofs, bioswales, building skins, solar panels on walls and roofs, cellphone radios attached to water towers, etc. But it can also be virtual. In a sense, the Possible City will be a piece of epistructure that attaches itself to the existing city and augments it with a collective intelligence and emergent structure.
fields.title: Epistructure
fields.text_html:
The design of infrastructure has the power to dramatically shape urban form and life, functioning as the conduit for the ecological, social, and economic flows of a city. As we continue to retrofit existing city centers to support burgeoning urban populations, innovative and sustainable methods of enabling and managing these flows are needed. fields.text:
City process in real life are too complex to be routine, too particularized for application as abstractions. They are always made up of interactions among unique combinations of particulars, and there is no substitute for knowing the particulars.
- Jane Jacobs
fields.title: The Particulars
fields.text_html:
City process in real life are too complex to be routine, too particularized for application as abstractions. They are always made up of interactions among unique combinations of particulars, and there is no substitute for knowing the particulars.
- Jane Jacobs

fields.text:
http://americancity.org/daily/entry/point-breeze-rising-land-values-revive-plan-to-seize-lots

John Kromer is a former head of the Philadelphia Office of Housing and Community Development who is now a senior consultant to the Fels Institute at the University of Pennsylvania. He said he was surprised to hear that the PRA had attempted to take property from active owner-developers. “The history of backlash against the use of eminent domain in Philadelphia and other cities has pushed their use of that ability in the opposite direction,” Kromer said. “Sure, in those instances where the private market isn’t working its magic the government steps in, but I haven’t heard of anything like this.”

paragraph

With no public dialogue, the PRA in April resurrected a seemingly dormant plan to build affordable housing in the Point Breeze Urban Renewal Area, a redevelopment zone created by the agency in 1971. Officials introduced an ordinance that would give them the power to condemn and acquire 51 lots scattered around the area, a majority of which are tax delinquent and owned by private individuals. Others are the legacy of prior revitalization efforts, owned by other government agencies or defunct nonprofits. The planned affordable housing development that the newly acquired lot would be taken for lacks definition and a sure source of funding, though it has been on the authority’s radar for some time.
fields.title: Gentrification and its Discontents
fields.text_html:
http://americancity.org/daily/entry/point-breeze-rising-land-values-revive-plan-to-seize-lots

John Kromer is a former head of the Philadelphia Office of Housing and Community Development who is now a senior consultant to the Fels Institute at the University of Pennsylvania. He said he was surprised to hear that the PRA had attempted to take property from active owner-developers. “The history of backlash against the use of eminent domain in Philadelphia and other cities has pushed their use of that ability in the opposite direction,” Kromer said. “Sure, in those instances where the private market isn’t working its magic the government steps in, but I haven’t heard of anything like this.”

paragraph

With no public dialogue, the PRA in April resurrected a seemingly dormant plan to build affordable housing in the Point Breeze Urban Renewal Area, a redevelopment zone created by the agency in 1971. Officials introduced an ordinance that would give them the power to condemn and acquire 51 lots scattered around the area, a majority of which are tax delinquent and owned by private individuals. Others are the legacy of prior revitalization efforts, owned by other government agencies or defunct nonprofits. The planned affordable housing development that the newly acquired lot would be taken for lacks definition and a sure source of funding, though it has been on the authority’s radar for some time.

fields.text:
The Urban Farming Guys are a non-profit collective in Kansas City who are experimenting with new ways of living in the inner city. They have developed a network of urban farms, aquaculture, decentralized energy, community engagement, and education and are working to create open source documentation of their successes and failures. From their website:

We are the seed that died and went into the ground. We are about 20 families who have purposefully uprooted from out of our comfortable suburban homes and moved into one of the worst neighborhoods in Kansas City. We each bought homes within a 5 block radius of each other and we put down our stake for the sake of the youth and the poor. What is going to happen to us … who knows, but this is certainly not a novelty idea, and please don’t try it yourselves without thinking it through. We are a band of pioneers. We don’t claim this is even a good idea…. it is our lives. We are cultivating the life of the innercity. The Police helicopter is our favorite bird. Neighborhood meetings are our drama. Dropping crime stats are our touchdown cheer. Just to see people walking their dogs around the block again is a sign of good things to come.

This is one type of experimentation that the Possible City hopes to enable. It's utopian in one sense, and profoundly practical in another. Its low-tech on the ground but enabled by a high-tech interconnected world. And the mission statement is inspring:

We believe that entire communities can be transformed from the inside out… from bust and blight to thriving and sustainable places to raise the next generation. And it can be done without massive programs, without ribbons and bows, and without changing a single demographic. We have set all theories aside and we’ve moved our homes and put our very lives on the line in one of the most dangerous and blighted zip-codes in the U.S 64127, Lykins Neighborhood, as our first prototype sustainable community. Together we are working to build economic forces from the inside out, creating jobs, building resilient communities with affordable healthy food access, establishing alternate water and energy solutions as we think globally. We are running hard to put the most innovative, accessible, low tech and reproducible solutions for self sustaining community into the hands of everyday people from the inner-cities to the Nations. We are beating a path for communities and villages to thrive in any economy. And we are raising up champions as we put these opportunities in the hands of our inner-city youth as we aim to intercept the path of the next generation. And lastly with your help, we are putting videos, diagrams, principals, parts lists and full technologies into your hands in an open source effort to make this reproducible around the world. Help us equip the next generation to thrive.


Not everything enabled by the Possible City will look like this -- we don't know what will emerge, and that's the point. But this is a good example of the kind of project the Possible City can cultivate and support. The next step is when there are two or three or four similar projects and the Possible City connects them together. We live in exciting times.
fields.title: The Urban Farming Guys

fields.text:
The Philadelphia City Planning Commission is working on their Central District Plan and wants your input. Join them at two public meetings this month to discuss how the City’s downtown and surrounding neighborhoods will develop in the next 10 years.
The meetings will be interactive to allow participants to help set priorities for areas like transportation, economic development, parks and open space. The meetings are part of the Philadelphia2035 — a blueprint for reshaping the city in the next 25 years through development projects and policies.

Two public meetings to determine the next 10 years. Holding public meetings is admirable and is a step up from the urban renewal of 1960s and 1970s. Blueprint plans likewise are better than no plan at all, especially when the alternative is hodgepodge developer interest. But these processes still fundamentally misunderstand how cities work. Someday we will look back upon this type of city planning with nostalgia at how well-intentioned but misguided it is.

Read more at Grid Magazine.
fields.title: Old School
fields.text_html:
The Philadelphia City Planning Commission is working on their Central District Plan and wants your input. Join them at two public meetings this month to discuss how the City’s downtown and surrounding neighborhoods will develop in the next 10 years.
The meetings will be interactive to allow participants to help set priorities for areas like transportation, economic development, parks and open space. The meetings are part of the Philadelphia2035 — a blueprint for reshaping the city in the next 25 years through development projects and policies.

Two public meetings to determine the next 10 years. Holding public meetings is admirable and is a step up from the urban renewal of 1960s and 1970s. Blueprint plans likewise are better than no plan at all, especially when the alternative is hodgepodge developer interest. But these processes still fundamentally misunderstand how cities work. Someday we will look back upon this type of city planning with nostalgia at how well-intentioned but misguided it is.

Read more at Grid Magazine.

fields.text:
Travel & Leisure magazine recently published an article on great restaurants in Philadelphia. In it, they reveal some examples of why Philadelphia is a good fit for Possible City:

Philadelphia isn’t some flashy food town easily swayed by passing trends. True to the spirit of its founding fathers, the city is a refuge for freethinking entrepreneurs who put their faith in community—passionate chefs supplied by the family farms of neighboring Lancaster County. Outsider chains don’t do well in Philadelphia, where the biggest restaurant empires are homegrown.

Entrepreneurship, community, networks connected to areas and businesses surrounding the city...these are qualities that the Possible City is being built to encourage. The restaurant economy is a peer network in the making, and it is happening because of the unique conditions that the city provides:

These colonizers expand because they can: a deep reserve of commercial property in an erstwhile industrial capital hell-bent on redevelopment makes Philadelphia a deal maker’s paradise. Kingpins aren’t the only ones taking advantage. Independent chef-owners can afford to step away from big-scene cuisine and showcase their talent in smaller spaces, often rehabbing shop-fronted houses with an inviting, lived-in look.

In some ways, it is an example of a new way of working and living -- where happiness and fulfillment are created through production rather than consumption. You no longer work in order to buy things to make you happy, you work to make you happy and to share the things that you produce with your local community.

Read the entire article at Travel & Leisure
fields.title: Why Philadelphia?: Restaurant Edition
fields.text_html:

You no longer work in order to buy things to make you happy, you work to make you happy and to share the things that you produce with your local community.

Read the entire article at Travel & Leisure

fields.title: Being Nicely Messy

fields.text: Helping cities to think and act reflectively, and holistically, is more of a social than a technical challenge. The world is filled with action plans that address individual technical problems. What’s missing is a way for all the stakeholders involved to collaborate around a shared objective: the health and liveability of the city as a whole. For a city to thrive everyone, by definition, has to be involved. It is not a matter or either social or technical innovation — we need both
fields.title: Social technical

fields.text:
The guys and gals at Sitra are producing great ideas for fleshing out a model for how a site like Possible City could work. Its uncanny how many of the things they are coming up with are exactly things I've been thinking. I swear I'm not just stealing all their ideas! For example, I went for a run this afternoon where I tend to do a lot of my best thinking. A passing though came to me of labeling projects S,M,L,XL (as a play on the Rem Koolhaas monograph of the same name). Later, when I got home, I decided to check out the Brickstarter website, which I haven't visited in a few weeks. They have a new post detailing a lot of interesting work on prototyping an application. And here's a quote: 

"The idea here is that a Brickstarter service usefully bundles up “packages” of work, and paperwork i.e. this is a “medium-sized” project (there would be S, M, L, XL), and the package consists of the necessary permits, advice, contacts, guides and so on."
Lots more interesting stuff to read here and ideas on how to shape things moving forward.
fields.title: Brickstarter
fields.text_html:

fields.text:
Another great resource at the intersection of planning, design, technology, and community. The Enabling City:

We know that markets are no longer the only sources of innovation, and that citizens are capable of more than just voting during election time.We have entered an era where interactive technologies and a renewed idea of citizenship are enabling us to experiment with alternative notions of sustainability and to share knowledge in increasingly dynamic ways. We now see artists working alongside policy makers, policy makers collaborating with citizens, and citizens helping cities diagnose their problems more accurately.
What emerges, then, is a community where the local and global are balanced and mediated by the city at large, and where local resources and know-how are given wider legitimacy as meaningful problem-solving tools in the quest for urban and cultural sustainability. Here, innovation is intended as a catalyst for social change — a collaborative process through which citizens can be directly involved in shaping the way a project, policy, or service is created and delivered. A shift from control to enablement turns cities into platforms for community empowerment — holistic, living spaces where people make their voices heard and draw from their everyday experiences to affect change.
fields.title: The Enabling City
fields.text_html:

fields.text:
As part of our grant application to Echoing Green  we were asked to describe the Possible City in 500 characters or less. That's 500 characters, not words. It was a difficult task, but one that has helped us to really clarify what it is we hope to build. Here is the result:

The Possible City is a platform for building authentic social networks, i.e. communities, around physical space and human ingenuity. Through a virtual network of untapped skills, ideas, and spirit, connected to a physical network of underutilized and undervalued spaces, the Possible City will enable citizens to create local communities and economies built around rebuilding their city.

Our grant is submitted and we wait until February to see if we are chosen as a semifinalist.

fields.text:
Using wikis and digital fabrication tools, TED Fellow Marcin Jakubowski is open-sourcing the blueprints for 50 farm machines, allowing anyone to build their own tractor or harvester from scratch. And that's only the first step in a project to write an instruction set for an entire self-sustaining village (starting cost: $10,000).

Call it a "civilization starter kit."
fields.title: Open-Sourced Blueprints for Civilization
fields.text_html:
Using wikis and digital fabrication tools, TED Fellow Marcin Jakubowski is open-sourcing the blueprints for 50 farm machines, allowing anyone to build their own tractor or harvester from scratch. Call it a "civilization starter kit."

fields.text:
As we continue to build out the Possible City framework, we will occasionally release small experiments that provide some useful information. Today we are launching a sneak peek of lotxlot, our parcel based mapping of locations in Philadelphia.

The sneak peek is a map of the publicly owned vacant land in Philadelphia. While the amount of vacant land displayed looks huge, it represents only about 25% of the total vacant land in the city. 

You can browse the map and click on individual lots for more information. If the lot is available for sale, you can click a link that will take you to the City of Philadelphia's website, where you can express interest in purchasing the lot. The map uses a number of open data sources from the City of Philadelphia. We will build upon this basic functionality in future releases, and improve on speed and usability. 

Find your vacant lot! If you have any comments or questions, don't hesitate to contact us at info@thepossiblecity.com or on Twitter: @possiblecity.
fields.title: lotxlot Sneak Peek: Public Vacant Lots
fields.text_html:

The sneak peek is a map of the publicly owned vacant land in Philadelphia. While the amount of vacant land displayed looks huge, it represents only about 25% of the total vacant land in the city. 

You can browse the map and click on individual lots for more information. If the lot is available for sale, you can click a link that will take you to the City of Philadelphia's website, where you can express interest in purchasing the lot. The map uses a number of open data sources from the City of Philadelphia. We will build upon this basic functionality in future releases, and improve on speed and usability. 

Find your vacant lot! If you have any comments or questions, don't hesitate to contact us at info@thepossiblecity.com or on Twitter: @possiblecity.

fields.text:
Today we are launching an update to our lotxlot application! Previously we were displaying only publicly owned vacant lots. Now we are showing privately owned vacant lots as well. This represents the extent of the known data on vacancy in Philadelphia: 41,890 vacant lots. 5387.52 acres of land. 8.42 square miles. 6.7% of Philadelphia. To put this in context, Fairmount Park proper (one of the largest city parks in the country) is 4,100 acres. 

We are confident in the data for public lots, as it comes from the cities new "vacant land front-door initiative". The data for private lots is less certain. We have gathered what we know from the city's land use database. The metadata for this data source contains the following disclaimer:

The resulting draft “Land Use 2010” feature class was joined with the Office of Property Assessment (OPA), formerly BRT, real estate database (2009). The PCPC used OPA building description values from the real estate table as the basis for land use categorization. All features were attributed to the 2-digit level. PCPC staff checked and corrected these categorizations using the following resources: PhilaShops retail properties database (2003); Philadelphia Industrial Development Corporation’s Industrial Market and Landuse Strategy report (2009), and Philadelphia Parks and Recreation (PPR) parks land and facilities database (2010). Under the Philadelphia2035 District Planning process, this feature class will undergo field verification as each Planning District project is completed. A total of 18 Planning Districts will be surveyed from 2011 to 2015. Field verification results in corrections to land use attributes and population of the 3-digit land use codes, which cannot otherwise cannot be determined without field inspection. Revisions to this land use feature class will be posted as survey work and evaluation for each Planning District is fully completed.

We will continue to update this information as new data is gathered. In the meantime, have fun exploring vacant lots near you and imagining what this land could become.
fields.title: 41,890 vacant lots. 5387.52 acres. 6.7% of Philadelphia

The resulting draft “Land Use 2010” feature class was joined with the Office of Property Assessment (OPA), formerly BRT, real estate database (2009). PCPC staff checked and corrected these categorizations using the following resources: PhilaShops retail properties database (2003); Philadelphia Industrial Development Corporation’s Industrial Market and Landuse Strategy report (2009), and Philadelphia Parks and Recreation (PPR) parks land and facilities database (2010). Under the Philadelphia2035 District Planning process, this feature class will undergo field verification as each Planning District project is completed. A total of 18 Planning Districts will be surveyed from 2011 to 2015. Field verification results in corrections to land use attributes and population of the 3-digit land use codes, which cannot otherwise cannot be determined without field inspection. Revisions to this land use feature class will be posted as survey work and evaluation for each Planning District is fully completed.

We will continue to update this information as new data is gathered. In the meantime, have fun exploring vacant lots near you and imagining what this land could become.

fields.text:
We've recently submitted Possible City to the Knight Foundation News Challenge for Open Government. Whether we get a share of the $5 million or not, these submissions are a crucial opportunity to evaluate and fine-tune our focus. The format of this challenge has been particularly useful, as each entry is open to comments from public and can be updated as feedback is given. This has enabled us to keep pushing to clarify what we are doing, and we've been updating our entry based on questions and critique we have received. Below is our mission statement in its most current iteration:

What's the Big Idea?

Possible City is an experiment in engaging the city's forgotten spaces to bridge a crucial gap in current urban planning practice. Top-down master planning, while cohesive and potentially visionary, is static and often insensitive to the needs of communities and individuals. Bottom-up advocacy planning addresses these issues, but can be fragmented and fall victim to "design by committee". The Web provides the virtual medium for a sophisticated new approach whereby an organized vision for an entire city can emerge from networks of citizens working to improve their local environments . Vacant land provides the physical medium, open to transformative new possibilities. Neither top down, nor bottom up, Possible City is a web-based framework for a symbiotic network of continuous experimentation, feedback, and synthesis more in-tune with the city as a complex and evolving entity.

Where to Start?

Philadelphia, like many post-industrial cities in the U.S. has an issue with vacant land. Current research estimates the number at over 40,000 vacant lots. This is over 5000 acres, or over 8 square miles of land. Perhaps unsurprisingly, much of this land is situated in under-served and economically impoverished neighborhoods and the individual parcels are small and fragmented. These conditions leave a combined area bigger than that of Center City largely incompatible with traditional economic and political structures; a whole segment of the city for which established planning processes and techniques have failed. At Possible City, we see these conditions as an opportunity rather than a problem to be solved.

What Do We Plan to Do About It?

The Possible City seeks to create community and economy structured around re-purposing vacant and underutilized land for innovative new uses. First, we plan to uncover people and organizations who are already working in this space and provide tools and community to strengthen and enhance their projects.  Second, we want to inspire and empower additional entrepreneurs, designers, activists, artists, and everyday citizens to capitalize on the opportunities presented through vacancy. Third, we want to connect these individuals and groups together to amplify their impact on a city-wide scale. Fourth, we want to feed this information back into governments and institutions so that they can develop policies and programs to support these emergent structures. We believe that the Possible City will emerge from the city's forgotten spaces, and that the plan for the  future city will emerge from the Possible City in a constant state of making and remaking.

How Are We Going to Do It?

City processes in real life are too complex to be routine, too particularized for application as abstractions. They are always made up of interactions among unique combinations of particulars, and there is no substitute for knowing the particulars.
- Jane Jacobs

Possible City is developing a set of tools to address "the particulars" and to network these particulars together in a holistic way. We will focus on the most fundamental building blocks of a city: 1. citizens 2. parcels of land 3. ideas. We are building a set of networked web applications to address each category.

Free Agent
Free Agent consists of user profiles of people interested in developing their own agency in the city - a place for individuals to express an interest in making a direct impact in their neighborhood. People can share what they would like to help create as well as what they are able to offer, whether that be time, money, materials, or expertise.

lotXlot
lotXlot is an application for mapping the city on a parcel by parcel basis, starting with open data provided by the city. It allows Agents to locate "Lots" with specific characteristics, gather up-to-date data about them, add their own data, and organize around them. The initial focus of lotXlot will be vacant lots, but every parcel in the city will have its own profile page and will be open to intervention.

Float
Float allows Agents to "float" interventions for specific lots in the city. The interventions can range from simple seed ideas to more fully realized projects. Once the concepts have been floated, other Agents can comment, join, support, and fund the realization of the project -- together they begin to "ground" the project - where the project transitions from the virtual space to physical ground. Related projects can be networked with each other to allow those involved to share knowledge and resources and begin to populate the city with new emergent physical and social structures.

The Networks and The Marketplace

What happens next will be powered by individual innovation and collaborative sharing. We are on the verge of a massive mutual co-arising.
- Bre Petis (founder of Makerbot)

By connecting, organizing, and mapping citizens, land, and ideas through the tools outlined above, Possible City will visualize the formation of  networks around topics such as Food, Energy, Health, Education, and Public Space. We plan to support these networks through the creation of virtual marketplaces for the exchange of ideas, time, and resources. We believe that citizens can develop more equitable and authentic economic opportunities by leveraging economies of agglomeration to compete with traditional economies of scale.

Together, we can build a community of governance focused on agency and experimentation. Rather than guessing about what urban redevelopment policies might work, we can test them out, find examples that work, and support those emergent networks of action. Possible City will not only give people a voice in urban development, it will also help to give shape to that voice.

fields.text:
Andrew Herscher is Associate Professor of Architecture at the University of Michigan. He also co-founded the Detroit Unreal Estate Agency, an open-access platform for research on urban crisis using Detroit as a focal point. He recently published The Unreal Estate Guide to Detroit, A guide to the emergence of alternative urban cultures in the wake of Detroit's economic decline:

Rather than seeing Detroit as an urban problem that needs to be solved, Andrew Herscher suggests that we regard Detroit as a "novel urban formation" and a site "where new ways of imagining, inhabiting, and constructing the contemporary city are being invented, tested and advanced...The Guide documents art and curatorial practices, community and guerilla gardens, urban farming and forestry, cultural platforms, living archives, evangelical missions, temporary public spaces, intentional communities, furtive monuments, outsider architecture, and other work made possible by the ready availability of urban space in Detroit. The Guide poses these spaces as "unreal estate": urban territory that has slipped through the free- market economy and entered other regimes of value, other contexts of meaning, and other systems of use. The appropriation of this territory in Detroit, the Guide suggests, offers new perspectives on what a city is and can be, especially in a time of urban crisis."
Book launch: The Unreal Estate Guide to Detroit
fields.title: Unreal Estate
fields.text_html:
